statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
David Wesley scored 28 points, hitting five
3-pointers, to lead the New Orleans Hornets to a 114-102 victory
over the Phoenix Suns on Monday.
article.headline: Wesley scores game-high 28 points in Hornets' win
article.linkText: Wesley's outside shooting powers Hornets past Suns
article.story:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- David Wesley made sure the New Orleans Hornets did not experience another fourth-quarter fade.
Wesley

Wesley scored 13 of his 28 points in the fourth quarter, including two of his five 3-pointers early in the period, as New Orleans defeated the Phoenix Suns 114-102 on Monday. The Hornets had averaged only 16.2 fourth-quarter points in their prior five games, losing four of them. They scored 31 in the fourth against Phoenix. "That had been on our mind. We need to make baskets at the end to win the game,'' Wesley said. "This was a solid game all the way through. Even when they made their runs, we were able to hold them off.'' Wesley's fifth 3-pointer gave New Orleans its largest lead, 89-72, early in the fourth. He entered having averaged more than 21 points in his previous seven games. He scored 34 in New Orleans' previous game, a 90-82 victory over Chicago that snapped a five-game losing skid. Jamaal Magloire scored a season-high 22 points, including several dunks, and grabbed 10 rebounds for New Orleans. Jamal Mashburn added 19 points, while Baron Davis had 18 points and nine assists for the Hornets, who made nearly 53 percent of their shots. Shawn Marion led Phoenix with 25 points, Stephon Marbury and Amare Stoudemire added 22 and Joe Johnson had 19. Marion scored six quick points to spark an 8-2 Phoenix run that pulled the Suns within 101-91 with 3:01 left. Marion then hit a 3-pointer two possessions later to keep Phoenix within 10 points, 104-94, but the Suns could get no closer. "You shouldn't expect to win games when you give up 53 percent shooting,'' Phoenix coach Frank Johnson said. "They hit all the big ones. We were not in tune defensively. We couldn't stop them. We couldn't get them to miss shots.'' The Hornets withstood a strong start by Phoenix in the third quarter when Davis made an early 3-pointer and Wesley followed with two more. Phoenix ended up shooting only 35 percent for the period and trailed 83-72 heading into the final quarter. Frank Johnson said his team lacked the hustle for a squad that came in with a road record of only 7-13. "We have to come out on the road with our hard hats on and for some reason we did not come out with that kind of energy,'' he said. "Defensively, we were a step slow and seemed not to be in tune.'' New Orleans led 60-52 at halftime after Mashburn hit a turnaround jump shot from the top of the key at the buzzer, capping a stint of seven baskets in nine possessions. The Hornets shot 57 percent for the half, in large part because of their success working the ball inside, where they outscored Phoenix 32-18. Magloire made his first three shots and had 14 points at halftime. Davis, playing his third-straight game after sitting out six with back spasms, had six first-half assists, setting up two dunks -- one on a no-look pass to Robert Traylor and another on a drive and scoop pass under the basket to Magloire. "Baron did an excellent job finding the open man and getting his teammates the ball,'' Magloire said. "That's what we were lacking when he was not here.'' Phoenix kept its deficit in single digits with solid outside shooting, including 5-of-10 from 3-point range. Stoudemire had 15 points in the first half but was the only inside force for the Suns early on. Joe Johnson -- starting because Penny Hardaway is out two weeks with a thumb injury -- scored 10 in the first half.

Game notes
Robert Pack, signed a second 10-day contract with the Hornets. He had nine points, five assists and two rebounds in 23 minutes. Pack was signed because guards Courtney Alexander (right groin) and Bryce Drew (inflamed left foot) are injured. Pack's minutes have been steady because coach Paul Silas has been trying to get more rest for Davis, who has missed eight games this season with back spasms. ... Stoudemire had scored 15 points just over halfway through the second quarter. His season average is 13 points per game. Seven of those points came at the foul line as Stoudemire had more free throws than the entire Hornets team to that point. ... New Orleans is 10-2 when scoring 100 points or more. ... The Hornets topped their high for points at home this season. They had 110 against Golden State on Nov. 8.
